newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: SIPTU votes to accept new Irish wage agreement.
newsitem.headline: SIPTU votes to accept new Irish wage agreement.

text.p: Ireland's largest trade union, SIPTU, voted on Wednesday to accept Partnership 2000, the latest wage agreement between employers, government and unions, a SIPTU spokeswoman said.
A detailed breakdown of the vote was not being released until Thursday, she said.
The agreement provides for wage rises of 9.25 percent over a three-year period and promises tax reductions of one billion punts over the life of the accord.
It also sets targets for the public finances, aiming for a general government deficit of not more than 1.5 percent of GDP and a debt/GDP ratio of 70 percent by 1999.

Acceptance by SIPTU, which has a membership of 225,000, makes it more likely that the agreement will be voted through when it goes to a full-union ballot at the Irish Congress of Trade Unions on Thursday.
SIPTU holds 70 of the 350 votes at the conference.
The bond market has been keeping an eye on the outcome of the SIPTU vote, fearing that rejection by SIPTU would make overall union approval of the accord unlikely.
Analysts have been concerned that if the agreement were rejected, it could put upward pressure on Irish inflation.
